title.value: Protein Sequence and Structure Co-design with Equivariant Translation
title.quote: PROTEIN SEQUENCE AND STRUCTURE CO-DESIGN WITH EQUIVARIANT TRANSLATION

extractions.description: This paper presents a novel approach for protein sequence and structure co-design that uses equivariant translation. Specifically, the method involves a trigonometry-aware encoder and a roto-translation equivariant decoder, which iteratively translate both protein sequence and structure into the desired state from random initialization, thereby accelerating the inference process significantly. The approach shows superior performance over state-of-the-art baselines across multiple tasks.

type.justification: The paper conducts extensive experiments and evaluates the proposed model on multiple tasks (antibody CDR co-design, protein sequence-structure co-design, and fixed-backbone sequence design) showing numerical results.
type.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin, and is able to design proteins of high fidelity as regards both sequence and structure, with running time orders of magnitude less than sampling-based methods.

name.justification: The research focuses on designing novel protein sequences and structures, which is a sub-field of computational biology.
name.quote: Designing novel proteins with specific structures and desired functions has been a long-standing challenge in the field of bioengineering.

name.justification: The paper deals with protein structure design, which falls under the sub-field of Structural Biology.
name.quote: Despite their great potential for protein design, the structures of proteins to be engineered are often unknown (Fischman & Ofran, 2018), which hinders the application of these methods.

name.justification: The proposed method leverages machine learning techniques, particularly deep generative models.
name.quote: Recently, machine learning approaches have demonstrated impressive performance on different aspects of protein design, and significant progress has been made (Gao et al., 2020).

name.justification: The name of the model proposed in the paper.
name.quote: To address the aforementioned issues, in this paper, we propose a new method capable of protein sequence-structure equivariant co-design called PROTSEED.

is_contributed.justification: It's a new method proposed by the authors in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: in this paper, we propose a new method capable of protein sequence-structure equivariant co-design called PROTSEED.

is_executed.justification: The model is evaluated on tasks requiring computational execution.
is_executed.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin.

is_compared.justification: The model is compared against other methods in the experiments.
is_compared.quote: Experimental results across multiple tasks show that our model outperforms previous state-of-the-art baselines by a large margin.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This is a new model; thus, there is no reference paper for it.

name.justification: The dataset used for antibody CDR co-design experiments.
name.quote: We conduct extensive experiments on the Structural Antibody Database (SAbDab) (Dunbar et al., 2014)...

referenced_paper_title.justification: Reference to the dataset's original publication.

name.justification: Mentioned in the context of comparing baseline methods.
